et: borrowed from French, going back to Middle French, "foolishness, stupidity," from {it}badiner{/it} "to banter, jest, play the fool" (verbal derivative of {it}badin{/it} "silly, foolish," as noun, "fool, simpleton," borrowed from Occitan, from {it}badar{/it} "to have the mouth wide open, gape"—going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*batāre{/it}, perhaps of imitative origin—+ {it}-in{/it}, adjective suffix) + {it}-age{/it} {et_link|-age|-age}
